awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Multi-Scale Characterization and Modeling of Anisotropy and Failure of Aluminum Alloys for Automotive Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Increasing the fuel efficiency of automobiles is a major driver for the automotive industry's recent efforts towards lightweight manufacturing. To achieve this goal, industry has identified the use of aluminum alloys in vehicle design and manufacture as an essential technology. Aluminum, with a density of 34 percent that of steel, is plentiful and recyclable, but has one-third the stiffness of steel, is more expensive to produce, has more complex material behavior, is less ductile with limited design experience within the automobile industry. To understand these properties and overcome these challenges, robust computational models of deformation and failure are essential. This Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award is a cooperative project between Industry (General Motors) and University (University of Texas at Austin) which supports fundamental scientific research aimed at developing enabling simulation technology for aluminum alloys through experimentation, modeling and validation. This will be achieved through a strong interaction between the university and industry research teams, including graduate student training through summer residency in General Motors labs and exposure of undergraduate students, including those from underrepresented groups, to current industry challenges. These interactions will provide broad impact by ensuring that the research generates new scientific knowledge with long-term benefits to engineering problems aligned with industrial needs, and will train future leaders in academia and industry with the skills to lead scientific innovation with engineering applications.

The experimental approach of the research plan includes conducting custom designed biaxial tests on tubes using two aluminum alloys to establish the evolution of plastic deformation up to failure under a range of triaxialities and Lode angles, while monitoring the deformation with three-dimensional digital image correlation. In-situ experiments on small-scale specimens under electron microscopes will be conducted, where the evolution of deformation under different stress states can be quantified up to failure. Small-scale testing will be performed using electron backscatter diffraction imaging in order to establish the evolution of texture. The modeling efforts include calibration of state of the art anisotropic yield functions and development of dependable failure criteria, and enhancement of the failure criteria using results from the small-scale experiments and establishment of the evolution of yield surfaces through crystal plasticity. The integrated approach involving well-calibrated continuum level plasticity and failure models, validated through their performance in simulating independent axial quasi-static and dynamic tube crushing experiments, is the major intellectual merit of the work. Transfer of the developed technology to industry can be immediate, as the crushing simulations developed and enhanced through this research are one of the most demanding tasks in automobile safety assurance.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
The project was a cooperative effort between Industry (GM) and University (University of Texas at Austin) whose main goal was to study the failure of Al-alloys used in the automotive industry for reducing the weight of automobiles. This was accomplished through the custom design and execution of experiments on aluminum alloy tubes under two combined loads: tension and torsion, and tension and internal pressure. The two sets of tubular specimens were loaded under different combinations of the respective loads to failure, monitoring the induced stresses and overall deformations. In addition, a full field strain monitoring method, three-dimensional digital image correlation, enabled the capture of the global deformation as well as deformation local to the narrow zone that precedes the final failure by fracture. The stiff test set-up and the displacement-controlled loading used enabled capturing the large deformation that develops in these zones up to the onset of fracture. The results unequivocally demonstrated that, at lower triaxiality values, failure strain decreases monotonically with mean stress. This important result refuted other failure criteria and has now been widely adopted by the community. The recorded stress-deformation responses were used to calibrate an anisotropic yield function based on which a constitutive model was developed. The constitutive model in turn was implemented in finite element analyses of the two sets of experiments and used to simulate the responses and localization experiments up to the onset of failure. Other important components of the constitutive model developed concurrently are methods of calibrating the anisotropy of sheet metal, as well as methods for the extraction of the material stress-strain response of an anisotropic material from within the localization zone that characterizes the response of a uniaxial tension test.

The simulations reproduced both sets of responses for all stress histories considered, confirming the fidelity of the constitutive model. Furthermore, the deformation in the localization zones were also captured up to the point when the test specimen failed in the experiment. Most importantly, this level of success was achieved using the calibrated hardening plasticity constitutive model free of any artificial “softening”. Failure can be established by the implementation of a failure criterion calibrated to the failure strain locus of the experiments.

 The project concluded with a set of impact crushing experiments on tubes of the same aluminum alloy using a custom drop-weight testing facility, monitoring the overall deformation with high-speed photography. The crushing experiments were simulated numerically using the constitutive model developed from the biaxial experiments. The first results were again found to reproduce the measured responses up to the onset of failure very well, which provides an independent validation of the constitutive model. Such efforts and others aimed at actual applications from industry will continue. Overall, the methodology developed provides a framework for the dependable prediction of failure in practical applications. The development and implementation of AI to the establishment of the anisotropy and the extraction of the material stress-strain response can improve the efficiency of such operations.

 


Last Modified: 02/06/2025
Modified by: Stelios Kyriakides
